Yesterday, I introduced H.J.Res. 59, a Congressional Review Act (CRA) joint resolution that blocks the EPA’s Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs under the Clean Air Act Rule (RMP rule). The EPA’s RMP rule trades safety for paperwork and delivers far more burden than benefit for businesses that have to abide by it. It wraps our businesses up in more bureaucratic red tape and makes it more difficult for them to keep their doors open, risking not only safety but also valuable jobs. H.J.Res. 59 delivers much needed regulatory relief for our businesses.  A regulation that was intended to make our nation’s businesses safer will do just the opposite. The EPA overstepped OSHA with this rule and makes our operating facilities even less safe than they were before. Sensitive information will be more easily accessible, setting a precedent that even Department of Homeland Affairs (DHS) staff have expressed concerns over.  With that information in the wrong hands, our nation’s security will absolutely be compromised.

This afternoon, the House will use the Congressional Review Act (CRA) to overturn President Obama’s Title X abortion funding rule. Title X was authorized in 1970 and was intended to provide family planning services to low income women, but today those funds are misused by abortion providers like Planned Parenthood.   President Obama issued a rule on his way out the door that mandated states had to use taxpayer dollars to fund health care clinics like Planned Parenthood. Today, we’re using the CRA to give states the flexibility to withhold taxpayer dollars from clinics like these. Overturning the rule doesn’t cut funding or access to coverage for women covered by Title X, but instead it redirects the funds to community health centers and hospitals that provide general health coverage.

Passing legislation isn’t easy. After introducing the bill to the House, it’s referred to the committee of jurisdiction. Then, hearings and a markup are held on the legislation, before it’s passed out of committee and to the full House of Representatives. Once a bill goes to the House floor, it needs the support of 218 members of Congress in order to pass and be sent over to the Senate for consideration.    That’s why I’m pleased to have several bills that I’ve introduced and cosponsored passed on the House floor, including legislation to get veterans better benefits to access career tech schools (H.R. 3218), help find cures for pediatric cancers (H.R. 1231), and provide regulatory certainty to Oklahoma’s energy companies (H.R. 2883). Do you support an open and free internet? So do I. On December 14th, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) will vote on Chairman Pai’s Restoring Internet Freedom Order which would reclassify internet service providers under Title I. This order isn’t doing away with net neutrality, it simply is reclassifying the internet as an “information service,” just as it was classified prior to 2015. Read common misconceptions about the FCC’s order and net neutrality on my website. http://bit.ly/2jA2bdp

WEEKLY WRAP-UP: As Americans, we are blessed beyond belief. Today, I spoke on the House floor in favor of the Senate companion to my bill, H.R. 42. We can all agree that we want our veterans to receive the best medical care we can give them. Introduced by Senator Inhofe, the Enhancing Veteran Care Act (S. 1266), allows the VA to contract with nonprofit accrediting organizations to investigate and report deficiencies. Just like you might get a second opinion from another doctor, this bill provides another tool for the VA to get a second opinion so we can ensure the medical services they provide exceed expectations. The full House will vote to send the Enhancing Veteran Care Act to President Trump’s desk later this week.

As a strong supporter of the Second Amendment, I believe Americans have the constitutional right to protect themselves -  and those around them - from harm. I am a cosponsor of H.R. 38, the Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act, and I was proud to vote in favor of the bill on the House floor today. Your gun ownership rights shouldn’t end at the state border and H.R. 38 ensures that law-abiding citizens’ with a state-issued concealed carry license or permit can legally carry across state lines.

Without a doubt, we want our veterans to receive health care that is second to none. S. 1266 will bring transparency and accountability to VA medical facilities so that we can ensure our veterans are receiving care equal to the best civilian hospitals. Read my statement along with the statement from Senator Jim Inhofe and Senator James Lankford on this big win for our veterans and their health care.
